characteristics.name: Straightness
characteristics.tolerance_zone: two parallel lines (surface) or cylindrical zone (axis)
rules: Controls straightness of individual line elements on a surface or the derived median line of a feature of size
When applied to a surface, no datum reference is used
When applied to an axis with MMC, a virtual condition boundary is established
characteristics.when_to_use: Long cylindrical features where bowing or bending must be controlled. Also for surface elements that must remain straight for sealing or bearing contact.
characteristics.when_NOT_to_use: When overall flatness of a surface is needed rather than individual line elements. Use flatness instead.
common_mistakes: Confusing surface straightness with axis straightness
Applying to features where flatness would be more appropriate

characteristics.name: Flatness
rules: The entire surface must lie between two parallel planes separated by the specified tolerance
No datum reference is permitted
The tolerance zone applies simultaneously to all points on the surface
characteristics.when_to_use: Surfaces that must be flat for sealing, mating, or as datum features. Critical for gasket surfaces and assembly interfaces.
characteristics.when_NOT_to_use: When you only need to control individual line elements on a surface. Use straightness instead. When orientation to a datum matters, use parallelism.
common_mistakes: Adding datum references (flatness never uses datums)
Specifying flatness tighter than the size tolerance of the feature

characteristics.name: Circularity
characteristics.tolerance_zone: two concentric circles in a cross-sectional plane
rules: Each circular element of the surface must lie between two concentric circles separated by the specified tolerance
Applies independently at each cross section
No datum reference is permitted
characteristics.when_to_use: Bearing journals, sealing surfaces, and features that must be round at each cross section. Critical for rotating components.
characteristics.when_NOT_to_use: When you need to control the entire cylindrical form (taper + circularity). Use cylindricity instead.
common_mistakes: Confusing with cylindricity (circularity is 2D per cross-section, cylindricity is 3D)
Applying to non-circular features

characteristics.name: Cylindricity
rules: The entire cylindrical surface must lie between two coaxial cylinders separated by the specified tolerance
Controls circularity, straightness, and taper simultaneously
No datum reference is permitted
characteristics.when_to_use: Features requiring full 3D cylindrical form control. Precision bores, hydraulic cylinder walls, bearing seats.
characteristics.when_NOT_to_use: When only roundness at individual cross sections matters (use circularity). When the relationship to a datum axis matters (use runout).
common_mistakes: Using when circularity is sufficient (cylindricity is harder to measure and more expensive to achieve)
Specifying too tight -- cylindricity is the most restrictive form control

characteristics.name: Perpendicularity
characteristics.tolerance_zone: two parallel planes or cylindrical zone perpendicular to datum
rules: The feature must lie within a tolerance zone perpendicular to the datum reference
For a surface: zone is two parallel planes perpendicular to datum
For an axis: zone is a cylinder perpendicular to datum
MMC modifier allows bonus tolerance
characteristics.when_to_use: Features that must be 90 degrees to a datum. Mounting surfaces perpendicular to a base, bosses perpendicular to a face, walls square to a reference.
characteristics.when_NOT_to_use: When the angle is not 90 degrees (use angularity). When no datum relationship exists (use flatness or straightness).
common_mistakes: Omitting the datum reference
Specifying perpendicularity when flatness would suffice (no datum relationship needed)

characteristics.name: Angularity
characteristics.tolerance_zone: two parallel planes at basic angle to datum
rules: The feature must lie within a tolerance zone at the specified basic angle to the datum
The basic angle must be specified with a basic dimension
Controls the orientation of the feature relative to the datum
characteristics.when_to_use: Features at an angle other than 90 degrees to a datum. Angled mounting surfaces, V-blocks, draft angles requiring precision.
characteristics.when_NOT_to_use: When the angle is exactly 90 degrees (use perpendicularity). When the angle is 0 degrees (use parallelism).
common_mistakes: Forgetting to specify the basic angle dimension
Using angularity for 90-degree relationships (use perpendicularity instead)

characteristics.name: Parallelism
characteristics.tolerance_zone: two parallel planes or cylindrical zone parallel to datum
rules: The feature must lie within a tolerance zone parallel to the datum reference
For a surface: zone is two parallel planes parallel to datum
For an axis: zone is a cylinder whose axis is parallel to datum
Parallelism tolerance must be less than the size tolerance
characteristics.when_to_use: Features that must be parallel to a datum. Opposite faces of a block, rails, guide surfaces, features that must track with a reference.
characteristics.when_NOT_to_use: When only flatness is needed without orientation relationship (use flatness). When the angle is not 0 degrees.
common_mistakes: Omitting the datum reference
Specifying parallelism when flatness alone would meet the functional requirement

characteristics.name: Position
rules: Position tolerance defines a zone within which the axis or center plane of a feature may vary from true position
True position is established by basic dimensions from datums
MMC modifier allows bonus tolerance equal to departure from MMC size
Composite position can control pattern location and feature-to-feature spacing separately
characteristics.when_to_use: Features that must align with mating features. Bolt hole patterns, pin locations, slot positions, any feature located by basic dimensions from datums.
characteristics.when_NOT_to_use: Curved or complex surfaces -- use profile instead. Features without a mating relationship where form alone matters.
common_mistakes: Forgetting to include datum references
Using position on curved surfaces where profile is more appropriate
Not using MMC when it would be functionally appropriate (missing free bonus tolerance)
Using diameter symbol for non-cylindrical tolerance zones

characteristics.name: Concentricity
characteristics.tolerance_zone: cylindrical zone centered on datum axis
rules: The median points of all diametrically opposed elements must lie within a cylindrical tolerance zone centered on the datum axis
Only RFS applies -- no material condition modifiers
Requires deriving the median line, which is complex and expensive to inspect
characteristics.when_to_use: Only when the median line of a feature must be controlled relative to a datum axis. Extremely rare -- required for precise dynamic balance or specific median-line relationships.
characteristics.when_NOT_to_use: Almost always. Circular runout controls the same coaxiality relationship more practically. Only use concentricity when the median-line relationship is explicitly required by function.
common_mistakes: Using concentricity when circular runout would achieve the same functional result
Not understanding the inspection cost -- concentricity requires deriving the median line from multiple measurements
characteristics.deprecation_note: ASME Y14.5-2018 retains concentricity but it requires deriving the median line/center, which is expensive to inspect. Circular runout controls the same relationship more practically. Use runout unless the median-line relationship is explicitly required.

characteristics.name: Symmetry
characteristics.tolerance_zone: two parallel planes centered on datum center plane
rules: The median points of all opposed elements must lie between two parallel planes centered on the datum center plane
Only RFS applies
Requires deriving the median plane, which is expensive to inspect
characteristics.when_to_use: Only when the median plane of a feature must be controlled relative to a datum center plane. Very rare in practice.
characteristics.when_NOT_to_use: Almost always. Position with RFS controls the same relationship more practically and is easier to inspect.
common_mistakes: Using symmetry when position would achieve the same result
Not understanding the inspection complexity
characteristics.deprecation_note: ASME Y14.5-2018 retains symmetry but position is preferred for locating features of size about a center plane. Symmetry requires deriving the median plane, which is expensive. Use position unless explicitly required.

characteristics.name: Profile of a Line
characteristics.tolerance_zone: two uniform offset curves from true profile in each cross section
rules: Each line element of the surface must lie within a tolerance zone bounded by two curves offset from the true profile
Applied independently at each cross section
Can be used with or without datum references
Without datums: controls form only. With datums: controls form, orientation, and location
characteristics.when_to_use: 2D cross-sectional profiles that vary along the length. Cam profiles, airfoil sections, extrusion cross-sections where form must be controlled per section.
characteristics.when_NOT_to_use: When the entire 3D surface must be controlled (use profile of a surface). When the feature is simple enough for form controls (flatness, circularity).
common_mistakes: Using when profile of a surface is needed (line profile only controls individual cross sections)
Not specifying the direction of the cross-sectional cuts

characteristics.name: Profile of a Surface
characteristics.tolerance_zone: two uniform offset surfaces from true profile
rules: The entire surface must lie within a tolerance zone bounded by two surfaces offset from the true profile
Controls the entire 3D surface simultaneously
Can be used with or without datum references
Without datums: controls form only. With datums: controls form, orientation, and location
Most versatile GD&T control -- can replace almost any other characteristic
characteristics.when_to_use: Complex 3D surfaces, castings, forgings, molds, any surface defined by CAD model. Also used as a catch-all for complex features where other controls are insufficient.
characteristics.when_NOT_to_use: Simple planar surfaces where flatness suffices. Simple cylindrical features where cylindricity or runout is more appropriate and easier to inspect.
common_mistakes: Overusing profile when simpler controls would work (flatness, perpendicularity)
Not defining the true profile with sufficient datum references for the intended control

characteristics.name: Circular Runout
characteristics.tolerance_zone: two concentric circles at each measurement position
rules: The feature must not vary by more than the specified tolerance during one full rotation about the datum axis
Applied independently at each circular measuring position
For surfaces perpendicular to the datum axis, controls circular elements (face runout)
Composite control of circularity and coaxiality (for cylinders) or perpendicularity (for faces)
characteristics.when_to_use: Rotating components where each circular element must be controlled relative to the rotation axis. Shaft journals, bearing seats, seal surfaces, flange faces. Preferred over concentricity for coaxiality control.
characteristics.when_NOT_to_use: When the cumulative surface must be controlled (use total runout). When only form is needed without datum relationship (use circularity).
common_mistakes: Confusing with total runout (circular runout is per-section, total runout is simultaneous)
Not establishing the datum axis correctly for the inspection setup

characteristics.name: Total Runout
characteristics.tolerance_zone: two coaxial cylinders (for cylindrical surfaces) or two parallel planes (for perpendicular surfaces)
rules: The entire surface must not vary by more than the specified tolerance during full rotation about the datum axis with the indicator traversing the full length
Combines circularity, straightness, taper, and coaxiality into one control (for cylinders)
For faces, controls the entire face for flatness and perpendicularity simultaneously
characteristics.when_to_use: When the entire surface must be controlled simultaneously relative to the datum axis. Precision shafts, bearing bores, critical sealing faces.
characteristics.when_NOT_to_use: When per-section control is sufficient (use circular runout -- it's less restrictive and easier to achieve). When form alone matters without datum relationship.
common_mistakes: Using total runout when circular runout would suffice (total runout is more restrictive)
Not understanding that total runout includes straightness and taper control
